Assistant Director Of the New
Jersey State Commission onUrban
Colored Population, later re-
named the Division Against Dis
elimination.


A former newspaperman,
Clarke was educated at Atlanta
University, Atlanta, Ca, and the
School Of Journalism at the Uni
versity Of Illinois. During his
years with the State Of New Jer-
sey, he directed research and
authored several studies on the
subject Of race relations, includ-
ing, "Teh Negro Citizen and
New Jersey Democracy" IA
Guide to Better Race Relations"
and several others.


Since leaving the government
in 1861, Clarke has maintained
his own public relations office
at 1925 Connecticut Avenue, NV.
Washington, DC.

Joseph A. Clarke, former Spe-
cial Assistant to Postmaster
General Arthur E. Summerfield
during the Eisenhower Admins
tration, has been named Special
Assistant to the Chairman Of the
Republican Congressional Com
mittee where he Will work on the
mobilization of the Negro vote
in Congressional races.


Clarke 8 appointment was an
r1ounced by Rep. Bob Wilson,
Chairman of the Republican Con-
gressional Committee. He said
Clarke will be working with the
committee in Washington and in
selected Congressional districts
throughout the country.


A native of Columbus Georgia,
Clarke has been a resident of
Washington, D. C.. since 1854.
Prior to coming to Washington,
he served for seven years as

The company operating taxes
in the state, excluding federal in
come and social security taxes,
were $11 million. Smith said
this figure brought the total tax
bill per telephone per month to
$5.32, including excise taxes.

Arizonans dialed 767, 1872, 900
local calls during 1868, and orr
ginated 1875, 900 long distance
calls. according to a year-end
report released by Mountain
States Telephone.


Lawson V. Smith, vice presi-
dent & general manager, reported
total Mountain States Telephone
investment in Arizona at the end
Of 1868 at SOS million. Net gain
in phones was 5000, bringing
the number of MIST phones in the
state to $40 ,59o at year end.

A clean sponge makes a fine
spoon holder on your stove top,
when you are cooking. It also can
be used to wipe up any spills, and
it can be rinsed right along with
the dishes.


Here's a two-in-one sugges-
ton: those tiny, inexpensive toy
or kitchen magnets can make a
quickie bulletin board out of your
refrigerator door. You'll find it
handy for compiling your shop
ping list and the children will
quickly find any message on the
entrance to their "after school
treat. You can also keep your
recipe card within view and free
from food spatters by using a
magnet on a metal strip or cab
met to hold the recipe while you
are cooking.


When preparing a package to
be mailed, apply colorless nail
polish over the address label so
the ink or type won't smear.


Iron in your water is exposed
as the villain of many house.
keeping problems in circulars
published by Purdue and Okla
homa State universities. Rust
staining of fabrics, porcelain,
china, glass, silver and other
articles, and a disagreeable me-
tallic taste to water, are the COM
mon annoyances cited. Both re-
ports recommend that you call a
water conditioner dealer for a
water analysis. The Lindsay
Company has developed a fully
automatic residential unit which
simultaneously softens the water
and removes iron of all types,
even when present in large guam
titles.


Looking for an unusual gift
to give next time you go to a
baby shower? Give the prospec-
tive mother your own dinner
gift certificate. Here's how it
works: when the mother and
baby come home from the hos
pital, take the family a hot din
ner ready to eat, and leave. That
first night home is hectic no
matter how we'll organized the
household.

Announcement Of the new ]. C.
Penney s store expansion at Tow
err Palza Shopping Center, 1875
East Thomas Road, has inaugu-
rated a new era In the continued
expansion of one Of the South
vests unique shopping centers,
according to James B. Phillips
of the firm of LaPrade, Phillips
& Lyon, owners.


"With the breaking of ground
in March, Tower Plaza assumes
a new role as a regional shop
ping CENTER" said MIR. Phil
lips. while continued and ex-
banded growth is expected Of Art-
IONA and Phoenix in the financial
and industrial centers Of Amer
lea, 1t is with extreme pride that
we announce that one of our prime
tenants has had such confidence
In our success that he has nearly
tripled his size in four years."


The new Penney 8. managed
as previously by Mr.. ]. E. Mont
gomery, will become a complete
hard and soft lines department
store, the first of Penney 8 ex-
pansion in this field in the State
Of Arizona.


New departments will include
cosmetics, furniture and floor
coverings, appliances, electron-
les, paint and wallpaper, hard
ware, sporting goods, building
materials, tires, batteries and
auto accessories, jewelry, photo
and optical, and many others.


The new building will cost
more than 2 million dollars. 1t
Is scheduled for completion in
1865.

Hire a Reddy Light Watch.
man and get all Of these
benefits for as little as
$500 a months:


l. A handsome lighting fixture
with powerful 7,OOO-Iumen
mercuy-vapor lamp.


2. BuiIt-in photo electric cell
which automatica ally turns
light on at dusk, off at dawn.
8. Complete installation on
an existing pole.


a. Full maintenance when.
ever needed.


5. All electric energy the lamp
will use.


6. Convenience and protec-
ton without costly investment.

Ray Schanen Of Milwaukee,
one Of the nations top profess
sional bowlers and Miller High
Life bowling, adviser, demon
strates how to roll a natural hook
without any conscious twisting
effort. It's done by keeping the
thumb we'll to the left, or at 9
o'clock on an imaginary clock,
from backswing to delivery. The
thumb will leave the ball first.
The other fingers, being on the
side of the ball, will impart the
spin necessary for hook.


Professional bowlers agree
that a hook or curve ball is pre-
ferred because it's spinning ac-
ton mixes the pins and leaves
fewer splits.

9 O'CLOCK FOR A HOOK

Harold E. Niles, District Manager OF
General Communications, Inc, Phoe-
nix, says: Because our answering
service personnel are on duty around
the clock, adequate parking lot light
ing is necessity. This lighting SerV-
ice is the perfect answer to our needs.
We make no costly investment in fix
lures, never have to replace burned
out lamps, and get brilliant iIIumina-
tion at low cost.
